natural problem: Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum?
natural solution: Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (if is_prime n then n else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n < 100"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (if is_prime n then n else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n < 100"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the greatest possible value of $n$ such that the sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, is 235 and the sum of these three prime numbers modulo 5 equals 0.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime (p n) \<and> p n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. p (n + 1) = next_prime (p n)"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. 5 dvd (p n + p (n + 1) + p (n + 2))"
shows  "GREATEST n. p n + p (n + 1) + p (n + 2) = 235"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime (p n) \<and> p n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. p (n + 1) = next_prime (p n)"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. 5 dvd (p n + p (n + 1) + p (n + 2))"
shows  "GREATEST n. p n + p (n + 1) + p (n + 2) = 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a sequence of prime numbers, $p_n$, with each $p_n$ less than 100 and $p_{n+1}$ is the next prime number after $p_n$. If there exists an $n$ such that the sum of $p_n, p_{n+1}, p_{n+2}$ is a multiple of 5, find the greatest possible value of $p_n + p_{n+1} + p_{n+2}$. The final answer is 235.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 3"
and h1 : "sorted_wrt (<) primes"
and h2 : "all is_prime primes"
and h3 : "last primes < 100"
and h4 : "sum_list primes mod 5 = 0"
shows  "sum_list primes \<le> 235"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 3"
and h1 : "sorted_wrt (<) primes"
and h2 : "all is_prime primes"
and h3 : "last primes < 100"
and h4 : "sum_list primes mod 5 = 0"
shows  "sum_list primes \<le> 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find three distinct prime numbers less than 100 that add up to a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum of these three numbers? The greatest possible sum is 235.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n > prime (n-1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. (prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "(GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) = 235"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235

 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n > prime (n-1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. (prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "(GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) = 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a sequence of prime numbers such that every prime number in the sequence is greater than the previous one and less than 100. If the sum of every three consecutive primes in the sequence is a multiple of 5, what is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive primes in this sequence? The final answer is 235.

a_4.formal problem:
definition consecutive_primes :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"consecutive_primes l = (length l = 3 \<and> (\<forall>i<2. nth l i + 1 = nth l (i+1)) \<and> (\<forall>i<3. prime (nth l i)))"

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<exists>l. consecutive_primes l \<and> (\<forall>i<3. nth l i < 100) \<and> (sum_list l) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "Max {y. \<exists>l. consecutive_primes l \<and> (\<forall>i<3. nth l i < 100) \<and> (sum_list l) mod 5 = 0 \<and> y = sum_list l} = 235"
end
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)



definition consecutive_primes :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"consecutive_primes l = (length l = 3 \<and> (\<forall>i<2. nth l i + 1 = nth l (i+1)) \<and> (\<forall>i<3. prime (nth l i)))"

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<exists>l. consecutive_primes l \<and> (\<forall>i<3. nth l i < 100) \<and> (sum_list l) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "Max {y. \<exists>l. consecutive_primes l \<and> (\<forall>i<3. nth l i < 100) \<and> (sum_list l) mod 5 = 0 \<and> y = sum_list l} = 235"
end

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the maximum sum of three consecutive prime numbers less than 100 that is divisible by 5. The maximum sum is 235.

and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"

 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.

shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"

a_5.informal problem: Consider a sequence of prime numbers less than 100, starting from the third prime number. What is the greatest possible value of the sum of three consecutive primes in this sequence such that the sum is a multiple of 5? The final Answer is 235.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p1 p2 p3 :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p1"
and h1 : "prime p2"
and h2 : "prime p3"
and h3 : "p1 < 100"
and h4 : "p2 < 100"
and h5 : "p3 < 100"
and h6 : "p1 + p2 + p3 mod 5 = 0"
shows  "p1 + p2 + p3 <= 235"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes p1 p2 p3 :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p1"
and h1 : "prime p2"
and h2 : "prime p3"
and h3 : "p1 < 100"
and h4 : "p2 < 100"
and h5 : "p3 < 100"
and h6 : "p1 + p2 + p3 mod 5 = 0"
shows  "p1 + p2 + p3 <= 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find three prime numbers each less than 100 such that the sum of the three primes modulo 5 equals zero, and the sum of the three primes is less than or equal to 235.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime a \<and> prime b \<and> prime c"
and h1 : "a < 100 \<and> b < 100 \<and> c < 100"
and h2 : "b = a + 2"
and h3 : "c = a + 4"
and h4 : "(a + b + c) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "a + b + c \<le> 235"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235
 ### Proof
 The primes less than 100 are, in decreasing order, 97, 89, 83, 79, 73, 71, 67, 61, 59, 53, 47, 43, 41, 37, 31, 29, 23, 19, 17, 13, 11, 7, 5, 3, 2.
 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime a \<and> prime b \<and> prime c"
and h1 : "a < 100 \<and> b < 100 \<and> c < 100"
and h2 : "b = a + 2"
and h3 : "c = a + 4"
and h4 : "(a + b + c) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "a + b + c \<le> 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: "Given three prime numbers less than 100, where the first prime number is 2 less than the second one and 4 less than the third one. If the sum of these three prime numbers is divisible by 5, show that the sum must be less than or equal to 235."

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n is prime and prime n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime (n+1) - prime n = 2"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. (prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"

 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n is prime and prime n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime (n+1) - prime n = 2"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. (prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2)) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "GREATEST n. prime n + prime (n+1) + prime (n+2) = 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the largest possible value for the sum of three consecutive prime numbers, all less than 100, such that the difference between each pair is 2, and the sum of these three numbers is divisible by 5. The final answer is 235.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime x"
and h1 : "prime y"
and h2 : "prime z"
and h3 : "x < y"
and h4 : "y < z"
and h5 : "x < 100"
and h6 : "y < 100"
and h7 : "z < 100"
and h8 : "(x + y + z) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "x + y + z \<le> 235"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three consecutive prime numbers, each less than $100$, have a sum that is a multiple of 5. What is the greatest possible sum? The final Answer is 235

 Starting with the first triple of primes on the list, add the remainders when each prime is divided by 5 and see whether the sum is a multiple of 5, in which case the sum of the three consecutive primes is a multiple of 5: 2+4+3=9, 4+3+4=11, 3+4+3=10.
 Aha! This means that $83+79+73=\boxed{235}$ is the greatest possible sum of three consecutive prime numbers, each less than 100, that have a sum that is a multiple of 5.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime x"
and h1 : "prime y"
and h2 : "prime z"
and h3 : "x < y"
and h4 : "y < z"
and h5 : "x < 100"
and h6 : "y < 100"
and h7 : "z < 100"
and h8 : "(x + y + z) mod 5 = 0"
shows  "x + y + z \<le> 235"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find three prime numbers less than 100, where each one is smaller than the next, and the sum of all three is divisible by 5. The sum of these three numbers should not exceed 235.
